text:
Justice Omotoso escapes assassination attempt 

Justice James Omotosho of the Federal High Court in Abuja narrowly survived an assassination attempt early this morning, just days after handing down a life sentence to Nnamdi Kanu.

He was rushed to a hospital, while security forces scrambled to secure the area.

His car was riddled with bullets, which was an indication of a calculated attempt to snuff life out of him .

text: Breaking News: An American lawyer has disclosed that Nnamdi Kanu has not received a life imprisonment sentence. According to him, the court's proceedings did not constitute a lawful judgment but rather a recitation of a non-existent sentence under Nigerian law. The lawyer emphasized that the judge failed to uphold the fundamental principle of justice, which requires showing the accused the written law they allegedly violated. "Globally, prior to imprisoning an individual, it is imperative to present them with the exact law they have broken and the relevant section that warrants punishment. However, in this instance, empty letters were read, rather than legal provisions," the lawyer stated. He maintained that Nnamdi Kanu is under political house arrest, rather than lawfully sentenced. "Even in hellfire," he argued, "God does not condemn a soul without presenting the record of their transgressions. You cannot discipline a child without explaining their wrongdoing. Consequently, how can an individual be imprisoned without a written law? Do not be deceived.

text:
Iâ€™ve Activated Strategy to Secure Nnamdi Kanuâ€™s Release â€“ Gov Otti 

Governor Alex Otti has responded to the life imprisonment sentence handed down to Nnamdi Kanu, leader of the Indigenous People of Biafra (IPoB), by the Federal High Court Abuja on November 20, 2025. The governor revealed that he has activated a strategy, initiated during Kanuâ€™s trial, aimed at securing his eventual freedom. 

â€œWhile Mazi Nnamdi Kanu can appeal his conviction, I want to assure the public that I have activated and will continue to pursue the agreed strategy until his freedom is achieved,â€ Otti stated on Saturday.

He added that some agreements reached with federal authorities were communicated during his visit to Kanu in DSS custody earlier this year. Otti criticised the initial mishandling of IPOB grievances, noting that poor management at the early stage contributed to the current situation, but urged for peace and restraint.

He warned politicians against exploiting Kanuâ€™s case for petty political gains and appealed to the people of Abia and the South East to remain calm and avoid inflammatory statements. The governor reiterated his readiness to work with well-meaning Nigerians and other stakeholders to pursue a resolution through dialogue and diplomacy.

He highlighted his past efforts, including public condemnations of the 2017 military invasion of Kanuâ€™s family home, advocating dialogue over force. Otti stressed that alternative resolution agreements made during the trial will now proceed following the courtâ€™s judgment.

He called for calm, assuring that with federal government assurances, Kanuâ€™s release is possible. The governor concluded by reaffirming his commitment to resolving the matter peacefully and restoring stability to the South East.

text:
My Reply to Peter Obiâ€™s comments on the insensitive, ill timed, problematic, divisive life sentence judgement given to Mazi Nnamdi Kanu:

Rules of the Hole: when youâ€™re in a hole, stop digging.
Yet here we are.

Gumi walks free. Fulani militants roam with RPGs and AK-57s in a country where civilians canâ€™t legally hold so much as a pistol.

But Justice Omotosho and co. have convicted Mazi Nnamdi Kanu on all counts, handed him a life sentence, and even blamed him for #EndSARSâ€”something everyone knows he had nothing to do with.

The optics donâ€™t matter to these drunken sailors in power. They believe the people have been subdued by fear and poverty. Itâ€™s the same brazenness we saw in the Mahmood-managed 2023 presidential election that Peter Obi clearly won, yet was stolen without consequences.
Our people say: when a mad man is dancing in the forest, something is beating the drum for him.

I am not from the South-East, but the gang-up against our most industrious and enterprising brothers and sisters is now visible to the blind and audible to the deaf.
Gowon said â€œno victor, no vanquished.â€ Perhaps his Whitehall handlers drafted that line, because Nigeria is still fighting a war that ended over 50 years ago.

Open bigotry and hatred are being mainstreamed. Whole regions remain excluded where it matters. Without justice, the peace Nigeria has is nothing but the peace of the graveyard.
I have never seen a time when more people openly believe Nigeria cannot work. The new national chorus is: â€œLet everybody go their separate ways.â€

Do we have no elders? Are they not seeing the unfolding disaster?
The supporters of MNK deserve commendation for their restraint despite relentless provocation. And now rumors say he is being transferred to Sokoto to serve a life sentence. Why Sokoto? Is he now the prisoner of the Caliphate?

Nigeria stands at a crossroadsâ€”no, a fork in the roadâ€”while our fate is being decided by slipper-wearing religious extremists wielding AK-47s, and the one who â€œgrabbed it, snatched it, and canâ€™t run with itâ€ is nowhere to be found.

Oga Presido, if you donâ€™t wake up and confront insecurity, you may well be Nigeriaâ€™s last elected president.

author.name: Stephen OSEMWEGIE
author.description: Husband, Father, Philanthropist, Human Rights Activist, Former Gubernatorial Aspirant Edo State 2024, Investor, Politician, Influencer. PhD Research Student CIU

quote.text:
Kanuâ€™s Conviction: At a Time Like This. 
The news of Mazi Nnamdi Kanuâ€™s conviction should compel every well-meaning Nigerian to pause and reflect. This is coming at a time when our beloved nation is facing severe economic hardship, insecurity, and the consequences of poor governance. 

Rather than reducing tension, this unfortunate development may well only aggravate it. 
I have always maintained that Mazi Kanu should never have been arrested. His arrest, detention, and now conviction represent a failure of leadership and a misunderstanding of the issues at stake. 

For years, I have consistently argued that dialogue, constructive engagement, and inclusive governance offer the path to lasting peace. Coercion becomes necessary only when reason has been exhausted. In this case, I submit that the reason was not only not exhausted, but was probably not explored at all, or not fully explored.

The concerns Kanu raised were not unheard of. The issues for which he demanded solutions were not insoluble. It only required wisdom, empathy, and a willingness to listen. In any functional society, such grievances are met with dialogue and reforms aimed at strengthening unity. 

The governmentâ€™s approach has only deepened mistrust and created an avoidable distraction at a time when citizens are overwhelmed by harsh economic realities and insecurity. While some may insist that â€œthe law has taken its course,â€ leadership often demands more than a strict, mechanical application of the law. Nations around the world resort to political solutions, negotiated settlements, and even amnesty when legal processes alone cannot serve the broader interest of peace and stability. Nigeria is not an exception.

The handling of Kanuâ€™s case mirrors the government as a man trapped in a hole but who, instead of looking for a way out, keeps digging deeper. It worsens not only the governmentâ€™s predicament but also the nation's collective condition.

If we truly desire a new Nigeria - a united, peaceful, and progressive one, our leaders must choose healing over hostility, reconciliation over retaliation, and dialogue over division. Only by addressing grievances with justice, fairness, and compassion can we move towards a future where every Nigerian feels heard, valued, and safe.

My ultimate call at this time, without prejudice to how anyone feels about the decision of the court, is for us to be optimistic for peace and reconciliation which will come in the end. I am also saying, thereby, that the Presidency, the Council of State and credible statesmen who love this country and who are interested in cohesion and inclusivity, should rise to the occasion, for a lasting solution. -PO
